title: Woe to Ephraim's Pride
shortSummary: Isaiah 28 pronounces judgment on the pride and drunkenness of Ephraim, symbolizing the northern kingdom of Israel, warning of coming destruction due to their rebellion and false security. The chapter contrasts human folly with God's sure foundation and wisdom, calling for repentance and trust in the Lord's righteous judgment.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - During the reign of King Ahaz of Judah, contemporary with the Syro-Ephraimite crisis

keyCharacters.name: Ephraim
keyCharacters.description: Represents the northern kingdom of Israel, characterized here as proud and drunkards, whose downfall is prophesied.

keyCharacters.name: Priests and Prophets
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who have erred through strong drink, leading the people astray with faulty vision and judgment.

keyCharacters.name: The LORD of hosts
keyCharacters.description: God who executes judgment and also provides a sure foundation and strength for His people.

definitions.definition: A metaphor for arrogance and self-exaltation that leads to downfall.

definitions.term: Precept upon precept, line upon line
definitions.definition: A phrase indicating gradual, step-by-step teaching or instruction.
An expression describing a false sense of security or alliance with destruction and judgment.
A foundational stone in building, symbolizing Christ as the sure and tested foundation of faith.

outline.heading: Judgment on Ephraim's Pride and Drunkenness
outline.description: The chapter opens with a woe pronounced against the proud and drunken leaders of Ephraim, whose beauty and strength are fading like a withering flower, signaling impending judgment.

outline.heading: The LORD’s Strength and the Failure of Religious Leaders
outline.description: God is described as a crown of glory for His faithful people, but the priests and prophets have erred through wine, causing spiritual blindness and corruption among the leaders.

outline.heading: God’s Teaching and the People’s Rejection
outline.description: God’s instruction is given patiently and methodically, yet the people refuse to listen, resulting in their stumbling and judgment.

outline.heading: The Futility of False Security and God’s Sure Foundation
outline.description: The people’s reliance on lies and false covenants with death is condemned, while God promises a tested cornerstone as a firm foundation for those who believe.

outline.heading: The LORD’s Judgment and Call to Hear
outline.description: God warns of His coming judgment described as a consuming scourge and urges the people to cease mocking and listen to His word.

outline.heading: God’s Wisdom in Creation and Instruction
outline.description: The chapter closes with a metaphor of agricultural wisdom, illustrating that God’s guidance is perfect and purposeful, demonstrating His wonderful counsel and excellent work.

application: Recognize and repent of pride and self-reliance, trusting instead in God’s sure foundation.
Avoid the pitfalls of spiritual drunkenness—be sober and discerning in faith and leadership.
Listen carefully and humbly to God’s word, embracing His step-by-step instruction for growth.
Reject false security in lies or worldly alliances and place confidence in God’s righteous judgment.

keyVerses.text: Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD, Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Christ as the tested and precious cornerstone, the firm foundation for faith and salvation.

keyVerses.text: But the word of the LORD was unto them precept upon precept, precept upon precept; line upon line, line upon line; here a little, and there a little; that they might go, and fall backward, and be broken, and snared, and taken.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the patient, clear teaching of God and the tragic consequences of rejecting His word.

keyVerses.text: Because ye have said, We have made a covenant with death, and with hell are we at agreement; when the overflowing scourge shall pass through, it shall not come unto us: for we have made lies our refuge, and under falsehood have we hid ourselves:
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns against false confidence in rebellion and deception, which leads to inevitable judgment.
